>From: "Chris Eppstein" <ceppstein@...>

>What's confusing to me about the assert class is that it only goes part of 
>the way. It provides a bunch of assertions but then an arbitrary line in 
>the sand has been drawn to say that these are all that anyone should need. 
>This is confusing.

What I am about to write is not a personal attack; therefore, do not take it 
personally. It is a comment on a general attitude that I have experienced 
and, in the past, held. Please do not write letters to the editor.

I used to believe, "if they are going to do something, they should go all 
the way, not just part of the way." My justification was managing 
expectations: if they do A, B and C for me, I expect them to do X, Y and Z. 
When they don't, I am disappointed. Why should they do that to me?! I have 
since changed my tune, as I find that attitude artifically limits some 
people's tendency to add some convenience where it is needed. Some 
convenience is almost always better than no convenience. Sometimes total 
convenience has too high a cost.

Specifically to Chris, your assumption is that Kent and Erich were trying to 
limit you by not including the kitchen sink. They did not. I'm certain they 
only added whatever they thought was needed at the time.

I maintain, however, that further customization is likely 
application-specific; therefore, I do not need it and I would prefer not to 
see it in the framework. As always, some exceptions apply.

J. B. Rainsberger
President, Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's build software that people understand
